questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with a right shift in Arneth count?
questions.explanation:
Classification of Neutrophil
  • Class I: Myelocytes and neutrophils with indented or horseshoe-shaped nuclei. (5%)
  • Class II: Neutrophils with bilobed nuclei. (35%)
  • Class III: Neutrophils with tri-lobed nuclei. (41%)
  • Class IV: Neutrophils with four-lobed nuclei. (17%)
  • Class V: Neutrophils with five or more lobes in their nuclei. (2%)

Toxic Conditions
  • Fewer cells in Classes IV and V indicate a left-sided shift
  • Active tuberculosis often shows a left shift.      (Option A)
  • Other infections showing a left shift may have superimposed tuberculosis

Extrinsic Factors Influencing Arneth Count
  • Certain drugs, tissue extracts, and hormones.
  • Trauma , various forms of radiation.
  • Induction of anesthesia.

Infections and Arneth Count
  • Acute progressive infections: Notable left shift. (Option B)
  • As infection subsides: Less marked left shift, may shift to the right.
  • Chronic infections: Other features like lymphocytosis come into range.

Normal Neutrophil Distribution

N1 and N3 constitute most neutrophils in peripheral blood.

Bone Marrow Stimulation

Presence of younger neutrophils (N1 and N2) indicates stimulation of bone marrow (shift to the left).      (Option D)

Bone Marrow Suppression

Presence of older cells (N4 and N5) indicates suppression of bone marrow (shift to right) (Option C)

Hypersegmented Neutrophil

Seen in megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency (shift to right)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about platelets are true?

options.label: A
options.text: Alpha granules contain clotting factors and platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)

options.label: B
options.text: Splenectomy causes a decrease in the platelet count

options.label: C
options.text: Interleukins IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, and IL-7 are involved in stimulating platelet production

options.label: D
options.text: Thrombopoietin is produced exclusively by megakaryocytes and regulates platelet production

questions.correct_answer: A. Alpha granules contain clotting factors and platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)
questions.explanation:
Platelets

General Description

Small, granulated, non-nucleated discs important for hemostasis

Size

1-4 µm in diameter

Concentration in Blood

150,000 - 450,000/µL

Half-life

~4 days

Origin

Formed from megakaryocytes in the bone marrow

Distribution

60-75% in circulation; the remainder mainly in the spleen

Splenectomy Effect

Causes an increase in platelet count (thrombocytosis) (Option B)

Thrombopoietin

Produced by liver and kidneys; regulates platelet production (Option D)

Membrane Receptors

For collagen, ADP, von Willebrand factor and fibrinogen

Cytoplasmic Components

Actin, myosin, glycogen, lysosomes and granules

Granules
  • Alpha granules: Soluble coagulation proteins (vWF, Factor V, II), adhesion molecule, growth factor (IGF, PDGF, TGF-β, platelet factor 4), Integrin, Cytokines (Option A)
  • Dense granules: ADP, ATP, Calcium, Serotonin

Response to Injury

Adhere to exposed collagen and von Willebrand factor; release granule contents upon activation

Deficiency Effect

Thrombocytopenic purpura (easy bruising, multiple subcutaneous hemorrhages)

Interleukins

IL-1, IL-3, IL-6, IL-11 stimulate platelet production (Option C)

Factors increasing platelet synthesis

Inflammation, thrombopoietin and IL-1, IL-3, IL-6, IL-11

questions.text: Which of the following coagulation factors is crucial for initiating the extrinsic pathway of blood coagulation?
questions.explanation:
Clotting Factor

Synonyms

Function

Half life

I

Fibrinogen

Clot formation

3-5 days

II (Option A)

Prothrombin

  • Converts fibrinogen to fibrin
  • Activates platelets
  • Also has anti clotting activity
  • Has growth factor and cytokine like activities

60 hours

III (Option B)

Tissue thromboplastin
  • Initiator of extrinsic pathway of coagulation
  • Activates factor VII

  • Convert X to Xa
  • Convert prothrombin to thrombin

Proaccelerin; labile factor; accelerator globulin (Ac-G)
  • Activate prothrombin to thrombin
  • Participates in activation of X

12 hours

VII (Option D)

Serum prothrombin conversion accelerator (SPCA); proconvertin; stable factor

Activates factor IX and X

3.5 hours

Antihemophilic factor(AHF); antihemophilic globulin(AHG); antihemophilic factor A

Activates factor X

8 - 12 hours

IX

Plasma thromboplastin component (PTC); antihemophilic factor B ; christmas factor

Activates factor X

18 - 24 hours

X

Stuart factor; Stuart-Prower factor

Conversion of prothrombin to thrombin

34 - 40 hours

XI

Plasma thromboplastin antecedent (PTA); antihemophilic factor C

Activates factor IX

45 hours

XII

Hageman factor; glass factor

Activates factor XI

-

XIII

Fibrin- stabilizing factor; Laki-Lorand factor

Crosslinks fibrin

10 days

Prekallikrein

Fletcher factor

Contact activation of blood coagulation

35 hours

High molecular weight kininogen (HMW-K)

Fitzgerald factor
  • Non enzymatic cofactor in contact activation
  • Act as thiol protease inhibitor

150 hours

Platelets phospholipid

PL
  • Temporary hemostasis
  • Synthesis factor V and XI

4 days

Deficiency of Factor

Clinical Syndrome

Cause

I

Afibrinogenemia

Depletion during pregnancy with premature separation of placenta; also congenital (rare)

II

Hypoprothrombinemia (hemorrhagic tendency in liver disease)

Decreased hepatic synthesis, often due to vitamin K deficiency

V

Parahemophilia

Congenital

VII

Hypoconvertinemia

Congenital

VIII

Hemophilia A
(classic hemophilia)

Congenital defect in the gene on the X chromosome coding for factor VIII; inherited as a sex-linked characteristic.

IX

Hemophilia B
(Christmas disease)

Congenital

X

Stuart-Prower factor deficiency

Congenital

XI

PTA deficiency

Congenital

XII

Hageman trait

Congenital

options.text: Platelet concentrates have a shelf life of up to 8 days at +22°C ± 2°C

options.label: B
options.text: Red cell concentrates stored with CPDA-1 have a shelf life of 35 days

options.label: C
options.text: Plasma stored at temperatures colder than –25°C has a shelf life of up to 3 years

options.label: D
options.text: Red cell concentrates stored with CPD have a shelf life of 28 days

questions.correct_answer: A. Platelet concentrates have a shelf life of up to 8 days at +22°C ± 2°C

Blood constituents

Preservative/

Shelf life

Uses

Temperature

Red cells

Citrate-citric acid- glucose (ACD) / 21 days

Blood transfusion

+4°C ± 2°C

Citrate phosphate dextrose (CPD) / 28 days (Option D)

CPDA-1(CPD with adenine) / 35 days (Option B)

CPD+ Additive solution / 42 days

Platelets

Plasma / 5-7 days
(5 days preferred due to bacterial risk) (Option A)

Platelet therapy

+22°C ± 2°C

Plasma

CPD,ACD, Buffered Citrate/ 3 years if frozen/ 3 months

Stable clotting factors (FII, FVII, FIX, FX, fibrinogen)

+4°C ± 2°C

Labile clotting factors (FV, FVIII)

3 years if colder than -25°C (Option C) / 3months if stored at -18°C to -25°C

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient needs an urgent blood transfusion. The image below shows the results of the patient’s blood group typing test. Based on the agglutination patterns observed, identify the patient's blood group?
questions.explanation:
Blood type

Antigens on RBC

Antibodies in Plasma

Genotypes

Frequency

O

-

Anti-A and Anti-B

OO

47%

A

A

Anti-B

OA or AA

41%

B

B

Anti-A

OB or BB

9%

AB

A and B

-

AB

3%

Common Rh antigens

C, D, E, c, d and e

Detection

Only in red cells

D antigen

Most antigenic, defines Rh positive

No D antigen

Rh negative; Forms anti-D agglutinins upon exposure to Rh+ cells (Option B)

Prevalence

85% of whites Rh+ve ,15% Rh-ve

Over 99% of Asians Rh+ve

Anti-D antibody formation

Requires exposure (transfusion or feto-maternal blood transfer) to D-positive red cells

Transfusion reaction onset

Requires massive exposure to Rh antigen to produce enough agglutinins for significant transfusion reaction to develop

questions.text: A pediatrician is reviewing the development of hematopoiesis in a fetus at various stages of gestation. They are particularly interested in understanding the shifts in hematopoietic activity locations as the fetus develops. At which gestational age does the bone marrow become the primary site of hematopoiesis?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Location

Key Points

Mesoblastic

Yolk sac, PSP, AGM
  • Yolk sac: Multilineage differentiating capabilities (starts functioning by the 2nd week of gestation).
  • Non-yolk sac regions: Para Aortic splanchnopleura (PSP) and aorta-gonad mesonephros (AGM) regions.
  • PSP: Gives rise to B-cell progenitors.
  • AGM: Contains pluripotent stem cells.

Hepatic

Liver, spleen
  • 2nd trimester of pregnancy.
  • Liver: Hematopoiesis starts at the 5th week, peaks at the 5th month, and ceases at birth.
  • Spleen: Hematopoiesis mainly in the 2nd trimester, less than liver.
  • Postnatal: Normally does not occur in liver and spleen unless demand is high (extramedullary hemopoiesis).

Medullary

Bone marrow (medullary hemopoiesis).
 
  • Marrow cavities appear by the 5th month (around 20 weeks) of fetal life, and become hemopoietic. (Option C)
  • Initial phase: Bone marrow exclusive for granulocytic and megakaryocytic proliferation.
  • Erythropoiesis starts in bone marrow towards the end of the 3rd trimester, and continues throughout life.
  • Postnatal: Hemopoiesis confined to bone marrow, extramedullary hemopoiesis abnormal.

Stage of Life

Stage of Hemopoiesis

Primary Sites

Embryonic

Mesoblastic

Yolk sac,

PSP (Paraaortic splanchnopleura),

AGM (Aorta-gonad-mesonephros) regions

Fetal (2nd Trimester)

Hepatic

Liver, spleen

Fetal (3rd Trimester)

Medullary

Bone marrow (initially granulocytic and megakaryocytic)

Postnatal (Birth Onwards)

Medullary

Bone marrow (vertebrae, ribs, sternum, pectoral and pelvic girdles, skull)

Abnormal Postnatal

Extramedullary

Liver, spleen (in case of increased demand for blood cells)

questions.text: A researcher is studying the behavior of hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) and wants to understand the mechanisms that regulate their self-renewal during tissue repair. Which type of stem cell division increases the stem cell pool during tissue repair?
questions.explanation:
Pathway

Definition

Mechanisms / Factors

Signaling Pathways

Self-Renewal

Produces at least one daughter cell with stem cell properties

Symmetric and Asymmetric Division

Wnt, Notch, TGF-β

Differentiation

Produces specialized cell types

Transcription Factors, Microenvironmental Signals

Wnt, Notch, TGF-β

Both Pathways

Balance between self-renewal and differentiation to maintain stem cell pool and tissue function

Interplay of intrinsic and extrinsic factors

  

Stem Cell Type

Description

Example

Totipotent Stem Cells

Can generate the entire organism, including the placenta.

Single cell from the 8-cell embryo stage.

Pluripotent Stem Cells

Can generate the entire organism except the placenta.

Cells from the inner cell mass of the blastocyst.

Multipotent Stem Cells

Can form only one lineage of cells.

Hematopoietic stem cells that give rise to various blood cell types.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the Burst Forming Unit-Erythroid (BFU-E) in the process of erythropoiesis?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a mature red blood cell that participates in oxygen transport

options.label: B
options.text: It is a type of stem cell that can differentiate into any blood cell type

options.label: C
options.text: It is an early progenitor cell in erythropoiesis that gives rise to CFU-E

options.label: D
options.text: It is a precursor cell in erythropoiesis that directly produces reticulocytes

questions.correct_answer: C. It is an early progenitor cell in erythropoiesis that gives rise to CFU-E

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding erythropoietin is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is majorly produced by the liver

options.label: B
options.text: Major stimulus for its production is hypoxia

options.label: D
options.text: The maximum erythropoietin receptor density is seen on CFU-E

questions.correct_answer: A. It is majorly produced by the liver

questions.text: How many oxygen atoms can one molecule of hemoglobin bind?
Which of the following is the primary protein responsible for binding and transporting free heme in the bloodstream?
A 45-year-old female with asthma presents with persistent coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath. Which interleukin is most directly involved in the activation of eosinophils in this condition?
